content.title: CEA vs CAS: Choosing Between Carotid Endarterectomy and Carotid Artery Stenting
content.definition: Evidence-based comparison of carotid endarterectomy (CEA) and carotid artery stenting (CAS) for treatment of carotid stenosis, incorporating patient-specific factors, anatomic considerations, and trial data to guide treatment selection.

cea.technique: Open surgical removal of atherosclerotic plaque

cas.technique: Endovascular stent placement with embolic protection
cas.development: FDA approved 2004 for high surgical risk

results.primary_endpoint: No significant difference in stroke/MI/death at 30 days + ipsilateral stroke at 4 years

icss.results: CEA superior to CAS for 30-day outcomes

acst_2.design: RCT comparing CEA vs CAS in asymptomatic

crest_2.design: RCT comparing revascularization vs medical therapy
crest_2.status: Closed early due to low event rate

content.statement: CEA vs CAS: Choosing Between Carotid Endarterectomy and Carotid Artery Stenting is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Carotid-Disease that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

learning_objectives: Apply CREST trial findings to patient selection
Identify anatomic and patient factors favoring CEA vs CAS
clinical_pearls: Age >70 favors CEA; age <70 may favor CAS (CREST)
CEA has higher MI risk; CAS has higher stroke risk
Type III aortic arch makes CAS technically challenging
Hostile neck (prior radiation, surgery) favors CAS
Always weigh stroke risk vs MI risk based on patient's comorbidities
